ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I feel like I became a better speaker in Spanish, while also learning new grammar that helped me express ideas more clearly.

I learned more difficult grammar concepts in Spanish that built on what I had learned in Spanish 130. We focused a lot on reading comprehension and spent a lot of time in class practicing speaking in small groups about things we had read or watched for homework.
Improved Spanish skills including writing, reading, comprehension, and speaking.

Knowledge:
Learned more about the cultures of various Spanish speaking countries in South America/Europe/North America
Learned how to read more developed texts and more nuianced vocabulary in spanish
How to talk more clearly about past events/ future events
How to talk about what someone else says
Skills:
Learned more about the importance of rolling r's in spanish
False cognates
How to avoid common errors when speaking and writing in spanish
Insights:
What life was really like in Mexico during the World war eras
I learned to speak and write and Spanish fairly well.

I noticed an improvement in my speaking skills thanks to the large amount of time spent listening to and speaking in Spanish in class. 
I learned a variety of tenses and vocab that allowed me to express myself with detail and accuracy.
I was immersed in the culture of Spanish-speaking countries.
I learned how to effectively study to retain large amounts of info in a compressed timeline.
I developed the skills and insights of grammar and vocabulary for spanish level 4.
The ability to speak and write in spanish.

I feel as though I developed a strong foundation of the Spanish language by taking both S130 and S140 with Professor Diaz. The class is set up in a way that encourages participation to interact with the language. I think that I was placed perfectly into L3 after the summer placement test, which allowed me to be successful throughout the two courses.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength was that we had two different teachers so it was great to get some variety in ways that the material was taught. The weakness was that the homework we would do before class was new stuff and I wish we spent more time learning it before hand or after to really clarify what we learned.

This course was very well organized and covered a lot of material in the limited summer session. I'd say one weakness was that sometimes it was a bit hard to focus when there were longer periods of lectures and explanations of grammar concepts. I think it would've been helpful to break up some of this with more interactive activities to keep students engaged.

Strengths: great professors and TAs who really cared about the students. Material in and outside of class was very helpful and immersive.
Weaknesses: more opportunities to work with classmates outside of class would have been helpful. Cultural project was also a bit hard to organize virtually.

Strengths:
The engagement was high from beginning to end
Professors are always responsive and willing to answer questions ASAP

Weaknesses:
Duration of class every day
Zoom Connection/


Some assignments posted on canvas were not there on the day listed in syllabus
The course made you work hard to understand and speak the language, as far as weaknesses go, I think some of the homework questions on the films and readings are a bit difficult.

Strengths: amazingly supportive teachers, a variety of learning approaches (in-class lecture, Supersite tutorials, textbook, handouts, one-on-one conversations with Martha). I found the Supersite tutorials to be very helpful!

Weaknesses: 
Answers to exams were not provided immediately after they were returned--this hinders our ability to learn from mistakes.
I would have appreciated the lesson powerpoints to be adapted to handouts as well since they're easier to print and study from. 
Answer keys to additional practice worksheets were sometimes provided, but not always. 
Finally, I think it would have been beneficial to assign more frequent "real-life" readings such as current news articles that could passively reinforce reading comprehension and vocab.
Having so much homework every day in the five week summer course is difficult, but I guess that's the price you have to pay to take it over the summer!

Even though I took the course online, participation was a strength. The course work was very organized and fair. I don't have any weaknesses to share, as I loved every aspect of this course and would recommend it to any student.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. It was nice to get this course over with in a few weeks rather than during the semester. I would recommend only taking this course during the summer session because it is a lot of work.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student that is looking to further develop their Spanish. It was nice to take it over the summer because it was an intensive course so you could really immerse yourself in the language for these five weeks.
Yes. It was an intensive course that greatly improved my Spanish in just a month.
Yes, there is only one way to get better at Spanish and that is by practicing. That is what you do here.
I would recommend the course if you want to learn Spanish. It's a hard for a Spanish course but it definitely pays off.
Yes, although the fast pace means that strong study skills and review strategies are absolutely essential.
Yes, the professors are great and I learned/re-learned a lot of Spanish!
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Every class was thought-provoking, challenging, and set you up for success if you put in the work.
